slide.text: © 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. USMS University™ Quick Start Training Risk and Underwriting

slide.title: Underwriting and Risk
slide.text:
© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Underwriting and Risk Underwriting and Risk group protects USMS against losses as a result of:
Merchant failure (going out of business) Fraud ID Theft Domestic and International Crime Unpaid Charge backs
Underwriting and Risk also protects merchants, cardholders and others against:
Losses due to Fraudulent Orders and Stolen Cards Funding of Terrorism (USA PATRIOT Act / OFAC)
2

slide.title: Underwriting and Risk
slide.text:
© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Underwriting and Risk Understanding the Risk:
A merchant account is, in essence, an unsecured credit line. A chargeback occurs when a cardholder disputes a transaction through their card-issuing bank. If a merchant has charge backs for any reason: (consumer fraud, merchant fraud, failed delivery, customer dispute) and is unable to repay, USMS assumes the financial risk of the charge backs. 3

slide.title: Underwriting and Risk
slide.text:
© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Underwriting and Risk Risk Exposure Example: Health Club with $500 annual membership Accepts $50,000 per mo. in cards for Jan., Feb., and March Closes Business in April Does not deliver services paid for Consumers have valid dispute Risk Exposure is 3 months X $50,000 = $150,000
4

slide.title: Underwriting and Risk
slide.text:
© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Underwriting and Risk Risk Exposure For Agents: Agents have zero risk unless Agent is complicit or a participant in fraudulent activity by:
Withholding known facts about a fraudulent merchant
Intentionally misrepresenting a merchant’s business or other important details
5
Agent Risk

slide.title: Underwriting and Risk
slide.text:
© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Underwriting and Risk Factors in Underwriting/Risk exposure based on:
Merchant type Card acceptance method (Retail, MOTO, Internet, etc.) Delivery Method (Over-the-Counter, shipped to home or office, digitally downloaded, future delivery, etc.) Borrowing capacity Merchant’s credit rating Cash flow Collateral (Assets, reserves, guarantors, net worth, letter of credit, etc.)
6

slide.title: Risk Threat Level
slide.text:
© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Risk Threat Level 7
Very Low Risk:
Small Ticket: Retail, Card Present, Restaurants High Risk:
Businesses with future delivery, higher ticket MOTO/Internet, Merchants with product claims-ie: weight loss, Large ticket merchants with poor financials and credit Low Risk:
Medium Ticket: ($50+) Retail, Card Present
Medium Risk:
Larger ticket-Card Present: Furniture and Appliance Stores Small to medium ticket: MOTO/Internet, Larger ticket service businesses: Auto Repair, Plumbers, etc. Very High Risk:
High ticket future delivery, High ticket MOTO/Internet with poor credit and financials, high ticket with product claims, outbound telemarketing

slide.title: Underwriting and Risk
slide.text:
© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Underwriting and Risk Merchants are either approved, declined or approved with conditions such as:
Approved monthly processing volume set by Underwriting Approved average ticket amount set by Underwriting Approved with Reserve Account (e.g. 10% rolling reserve) Approved with Deposit Day Delay (additional delay in deposits to allow analysis of transactions) Approved via a USMS secondary processing partner (special high risk providers)
8
APPROVED

slide.title: Underwriting and Risk
slide.text:
© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Underwriting and Risk Underwriting Guidelines - How to get fast approvals:
Submit completed application package. If faxed, ensure everything is legible. Include legible ID(s). (Per Section 326: USA PATRIOT Act of 2001)- driver’s license, photo ID or passport. Although it has an impact, poor credit alone does not mean a decline. It does help if the principal(s) have good credit. Documentation verifying the merchant’s business location. Larger accounts require additional financial statements. Not on Prohibited Merchant List (found on agent web site).
9

slide.title: Underwriting and Risk
slide.text: © 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Underwriting and Risk Additional Documentation Requirements include: Clear copy of voided check or signed bank letter (required). MOTO (mail order telephone order) form COMPLETETELY filled out with details for all MOTO businesses. Cover Letter as follows: Unless the business is obvious- such as a restaurant or dentist, explain in detail, what is being sold and how it is being sold. There are MANY times where the product or service is not clear or how it is sold, Underwriting is then forced to ask for more information, which places account on hold. Marketing material or samples of product 10

slide.title: Underwriting and Risk
slide.text:
© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Underwriting and Risk Required for all applicants: Completed and signed Merchant Application Pre-printed Voided Check or Bank Letter Valid Government-issued ID(s) Social Security Numbers of all Principals Federal Tax ID Number (EIN) Personal Guarantee(s) (some exceptions) Documentation validating Business Address
11
Acceptance of Merchant Agreement

slide.title: Underwriting and Risk
slide.text:
© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Underwriting and Risk Financials Required: CARD PRESENT (RETAIL) SALES: Monthly Volume greater than $100,000 and/or average ticket greater than $1,500 may require financial statements. It is always best to get them to be sure. CARD-NOT-PRESENT (MOTO/INTERNET) SALES: Monthly Volume greater than $50,000 and/or average ticket greater than $500 – will require financial statements. If the merchant continues to process excessive large tickets or volume exceeds limit, they may be in violation of contract and the account will then need to be re-underwritten requesting financials. If a merchant signs an application with a MAX ticket exceeding the amounts above, financials should be provided prior to approval.
12

slide.title: Underwriting and Risk
slide.text:
© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Underwriting and Risk Financials may also be required: If an account poses a risk to USMS for the following reasons: Large ticket transactions Large volume Risk of charge backs Risk of rejects Large number of credit returns Note: Based on the above information it should be understood that financials may be required for initial underwriting, or at anytime while the merchant is processing with USMS
13

slide.title: Underwriting and Risk
slide.text:
© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Underwriting and Risk Financials include: Profit and Loss Statements Shows income and expenses Balance Sheet Assets versus liabilities Tax Returns Business returns for established businesses Personal returns if business is new Personal Financials: Personal profit and loss Statement of net worth (same as balance sheet) Personal tax returns
14

slide.title: Underwriting and Risk
slide.text:
© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Underwriting and Risk Financials:
Bank statements and previous processing statements are often required documents and NOT considered part of financials. The more information you provide, the easier it is to underwrite the account. If financials are required, USMS may or may not require personal financials. It’s always better to get more than less.
15

slide.title: Underwriting and Risk
slide.text:
© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Underwriting and Risk Additional Underwriting Requirements:
Merchant must not appear on MATCH (CTMF-Combined Terminated Merchant File). No open bankruptcies (Proof of discharge required). Business and DDA (demand deposit account- business checking account) must be established in the U.S.A. Previous statements are helpful (if merchant previously accepted bankcards). No future delivery over 90 days (some exceptions apply). Business model must make sense by all logical means.
16

slide.title: Underwriting and Risk
slide.text:
© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Underwriting and Risk Auto Approval Accounts (AAA):
Gets boarded faster. Underwriting looks over account after boarding. Must be Qualified (See Operating Bulletin). Must be on AAA Merchant Type list. Examples: Restaurants, small ticket retail, convenience stores, dentists, dry cleaners, hair salons, and most low risk businesses.
17
APPROVED

slide.title: Underwriting and Risk
slide.text:
© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Underwriting and Risk Acceptable documentation to validate business address and goods/services sold:
Business License Current Utility Bill Contracts for Sale of Goods/Services Marketing Materials Invoices for Inventory Purchases Current merchant processing statements Professional License (doctor, contractor, insurance agent) Tax Permits Property Tax Assessment Invoices for Customer Sales
18

slide.title: Underwriting and Risk
slide.text:
© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Underwriting and Risk Prohibited Merchants:
Certain types of businesses have an industry track record of high risk and charge backs. They pose too much risk that we simply avoid boarding these. USMS has secondary processing relationships which may accept some of these accounts and you will earn income on them. Some merchant categories are prohibited from card acceptance by the Visa and MasterCard Regulations, such as: Card-Not-Present tobacco sales in the US. No US acquirer will be able to board the account. Any type of illegal business is of course prohibited. Certain merchant types are prohibited as Card-Not-Present (CNP) sales only.
19

slide.title: Underwriting and Risk
slide.text:
© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Underwriting and Risk 900 Number / Pay Calls Adult Material / Pornography Airlines / Air Carriers Business Opportunities (some) Buying / Shopping Club Calling Cards / Pre-paid Cards Collection Agencies Computer Bulletin Boards Credit Repair / Debt Counseling
20
Credit Card Insurance Companion / Dating Services Computer Hardware Sales (Home-based) Cruise Lines Direct Marketing – Travel Related Investment Opportunities ISPs (Home-based)
The Following are USMS prohibited merchants:

slide.title: Underwriting and Risk
slide.text:
© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Underwriting and Risk 21
Prohibited merchants, Page 2: Jewelry (CNP High Ticket) Massage Parlors (Non-licensed) Multi-Level Marketing Mortgage Services (Loan Payments) Products with Unreasonable Guarantees Pharmaceuticals / Drugs (on-line) Psychics / Horoscopes Securities Sales / Brokers Sports Forecasting Telemarketing – Outbound Ticket Sales Timeshare Sales Tobacco Products (CNP) ISPs (Home-based)

slide.title: Underwriting and Risk
slide.text:
© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Underwriting and Risk 22
Prohibited merchants, Page 3: Travel Agencies Travel Clubs / Promotions Video Text Water Purifiers Weight Loss Centers / Diet Program Wholesale Clubs Electronics (CNP High Ticket) Escort Services Gaming Activities / Advice / Lottery Hair Restoration Services / Products Infomercials

slide.title: Underwriting and Risk
slide.text:
© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Underwriting and Risk Top Risk Questions:
When and why Financials may be requested? (answered) Why does Risk verify transactions and the process of verification? When a transaction is approved (authorized), why does risk still follow validation process? What is a chargeback and who is liable for the loss of funds? (answered) Please explain the reserve account and Rolling Release Why is it so crucial to have EVERYTHING completed on a USMS application and attached documentation What is TMF (terminated merchant file) or having a merchant placed on MATCH (Member Alert to control high-risk)
23

slide.title: Underwriting and Risk
slide.text:
© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Underwriting and Risk Why the Risk Department verifies transactions:
A transaction may result in a loss to both the merchant and USMS. A transaction may be considered a violation such as cash advances. Any single transaction poses a liability of up to 270 days (9 months) for a chargeback. With this in mind if verification is successful (with the merchant, cardholder and card issuing bank) the risk is minimized. When a transaction is approved (authorized), why does Risk still follow validation process?: When transactions are authorized through a terminal or a gateway, it does not guarantee that the transaction is valid or not fraudulent. When the transaction is authorized via the terminal, gateway, etc., the card-issuing bank is only authorizing the transaction. Stating, there are enough funds on the credit card and it is not marked stolen or closed.
24

slide.title: Underwriting and Risk
slide.text:
© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Underwriting and Risk Verifying a transaction consists of:
Contacting the merchant and requesting invoice A decision is made to hold or not to hold funds Verifying transactions with card holder and card issuing bank A decision is made to release funds and mark validated or if further information is needed.
25

slide.title: Underwriting and Risk
slide.text:
© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Underwriting and Risk Reserve Accounts and Rolling Releases:
A reserve account is a non-interest bearing deposit account with the acquirer established for “riskier” businesses. The purpose of a reserve account is to hold sufficient funds to satisfy the merchants current and future obligations (potential charge backs) Reserve accounts can be 5% to 25% or more of merchants volume A rolling release is a periodic release of funds from a reserve account: Example- 6 months rolling reserve means that amounts reserved in the first month would be released in the 7th month.
26

slide.title: Underwriting and Risk
slide.text:
© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Underwriting and Risk Why is it so crucial to have EVERYTHING completed on a USMS application and attached documentation?
Each detail in the file can greatly help speed the approval process. AVOID STIPS later- Complete Application Application has important factors for Underwriting such as: Years in business Valid phone numbers (business, residence and contact) Drivers license number and date of birth ALL initials and signatures Percentage of swiped transactions vs. Keyed (bankcard sales profile)
27

slide.title: Underwriting and Risk
slide.text:
© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Underwriting and Risk What is CTMF (Combined Terminated Merchant File) or placing a merchant MATCH (Member Alert to Control High-Risk)?:
A merchant may be placed on MATCH/CTMF due to breach of contract with USMS or a previous processor for reasons such as:
Excessive charge backs Factoring (using more then one processor at a time) Fraud Unpaid rejects or excessively obligations We as a processor are required by our bank and Visa/MasterCard to TMF the merchant. This basically means the merchant can no longer process credit cards.
28
